utterances: David Welna, NPR News, the Capitol.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.

And I'm Robert Siegel.
Monday is Presidents' Day.
But what about a more overlooked group, the vice presidents?
Especially, the overlooked vice presidents.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC, ""HAIL COLUMBIA"")
Vice presidents do have their own march - this one called ""Hail Columbia."" It's the song that's supposed to be played when a vice president of the United States enters a room.
Forty-seven men have been vice president.
John Adams was the first one and he ascended to the presidency when George Washington's second term ended.
But only 14 other vice presidents have gone on to the top job.
And it's the rest of them we want to salute now; those who quietly shrank from the national stage.
[POST-BROADCAST CORRECTION: Only 13 other vice presidents have gone on to the presidency, for a total of 14.]
It's been tough for many of them.
Vice presidents have been known to endure obscurity and even ridicule.
Prominent U.S.
Senator Hubert Humphrey became President Lyndon Johnson's vice president, only to become the target of musical satire by Tom Lehrer.
(Singing) What ever became of Hubert?
Has anyone heard a thing?
Once he shone on his own, now he sits home alone and waits for the phone to ring.
The vice presidency swallowed Hubert Humphrey, just as it did Dan Tompkins, Billy King, Bill Wheeler, Tommy Hendricks, Levi Morton, and many more.
Yes, it is possible to be a heartbeat beat away from the presidency, yet as functional as the appendix.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC, ""HAIL COLUMBIA"")
Now, there certainly are ways to escape being forgotten as vice president.
Thomas Jefferson's first vice president was Aaron Burr.
He kept his name in the history books by taking the shoot-someone-prominent approach.
That's why everyone knows his name.
But as for Jefferson's vice president in his second term - you know, George Clinton?
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""WE WANT THE FUNK"")
No, not that George Clinton, the funk master.
We're talking about New York Governor George Clinton.
Indeed, New York has given us more vice presidents than any other state.
Vice President Clinton is honored with a bridge over the Hudson River, the George Clinton Kingston-Rhinecliff Bridge.
Frankly, most people call it the Rhinecliff Bridge.
That's the Reverend Kenneth Walsh.
He's pastor of the Old Dutch Church in Kingston.
Vice President George Clinton is buried in its cemetery.
Actually, Clinton was buried first in Washington.
He was re-interred in Reverend Walsh's graveyard.
When he was buried here in 1909, it was with great ceremony.
There are actually photographs of people standing next to his skeleton - rather gruesome.
Another VP New Yorker, another churchyard.
My name is Roger Walters.
I'm the junior warden at the St. Mark's Church in the Bowery.
I'm standing in the west yard near the statue that we have of Daniel D.
Tompkins, vice president under President James Monroe.
According to historians, Tompkins spent much of his vice presidency drunk.
Despite that, Manhattan's Tompkins Square is named after him.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC, ""HAIL COLUMBIA"")
James Schoolcraft Sherman was another New York vice president.
He served under William Howard Taft, which sounds very painful, come to think of it.
Sherman, according to sources who keep track of such things, was the first sitting vice president to fly in an airplane.
And folks in his hometown of Utica, New York have not forgotten him.
James Schoolcraft Sherman put Oneida County in central New York on the national spotlight.
That's Frank Tomano, volunteer at the Oneida County Historical Society Museum.
There are two streets named after him - Sherman Place and Sherman Avenue.
And there is a statue of the man on one of Utica's busiest highways.
If you go by where our vice presidents were born, then Kentucky is the second busiest hatchery of VPs.
But Indiana lays claim to the second most vice presidents associated with a state.
We're a hotbed for vice presidents.
Dan Johns is curator of the Quayle Vice Presidential Learning Center in Huntington, Indiana.
He includes men associated with Indiana, but born elsewhere.
Schuyler Colfax, Charles Warren Fairbanks, Thomas Andrew Hendricks, Thomas Riley Marshall.
And, of course, the center's founder, J.
Danforth Quayle.
Let's concentrate on Thomas Riley Marshall.
He was Woodrow Wilson's vice president.
He was considered to be a funny guy.
While he was presiding over the Senate, as a long-winded member was cataloging the nation's many needs, Marshall whispered an immortal phrase.
What this country needs is a really good five-cent cigar.
I've been trying to do the inflation in my head.
A five-cent cigar in the Wilson era was not as cheap a cigar as it would have been many, many years later.
I'm thinking it would not be.

Jason Beaubien, NPR News, Cairo.
No, I don't thinks so.
We had to go to school to learn how to do them and I do not have a computer and it was very simple for me, so I don't think that the voters will have too much problem.
Take us back to that first day in 1948 when you worked at the polls there.
What was it like?
Oh, we were in little booths about the half of the size of a garage.
And it had a little pot bellied stove in it, and we sat at a table and there were the booths, of course, and the people that were waiting to vote had to wait outside because they were so small.
And you had a great big ballot the size of a sheet of newspaper with both parties on it.
But up at the top, you could make an X and you would just vote for whichever party and that meant everybody in that party got voted for.
And when they were - when we were all done, we were there until 3:00, 4:00 sometimes in the morning counting the ballots because we had to do all of the counting off of the paper.
So that was a very long day.
So people would just vote just for one particular political party.
They wouldn't necessarily vote for candidates.
No. They would just be voting party.
And there were quite a number of them then that did that.
I don't think there would be as many anymore.
I think maybe we're educated a little better to know that sometimes it isn't the best person.
So are you going to go back in two years, 2008, will you sign up to be a poll worker then?
Yes.
Definitely.
Patricia Speicher of Summit County, Ohio.
She's been a poll worker for 58 years.
And Mrs. Speicher, thank you for joining us.
